Unlike the United States, Switzerland and most other developed countries in the world, among
which most of the Member States of the EU including France, Germany, Italy, Portugal and,
Spain,  the United Kingdom strips its citizens of the right to vote in Parliamentary elections for
the mere fact of having resided abroad for more than 15 years.

Exceptions exist for the military, civil servants and British Council employees. But all other
British expats, including English teachers at schools other than the British Council, lose the
right to vote after 15 years abroad. Apart from expats, the only other British citizens who do
not enjoy the right to vote are children, individuals who suffer from mental illnesses such
that they are confined within mental institutions, and criminals whilst imprisoned.

Most British citizens living abroad still maintain an interest in the way things are run and would like a chance to voice these concerns. I believe we deserve that.
